facts.text: In 1927, a tax was imposed on cotton mills in Indore in Holkar State by the then Ruler in respect of profits, gains and income of such mills under the Indore Industrial Tax Rules, 1947 promulgated by the Ruler.

Procedure under Tax Rules: assessment by board of assessing officers, appeal to Member in-charge of Commerce and Industry Department, second appeal to Government; Rule 17 vests power to make rules in Government subject to previous publication except first occasion; Rule 18 requires publication in State Gazette for force of law; Rule 19 empowers Member to make subsidiary rules not inconsistent.
May 28, 1948: Holkar State merged to form State of Madhya Bharat.
July 19, 1948: State of Madhya Bharat acceded to India.

Ordinance No. 1 of 1948 promulgated by Rajpramukh of Madhya Bharat for peace and good government, superseded by Act 1 of 1948 effective December 13, 1948; Section 4 continues existing laws until repealed/amended; Section 5 empowers Government by notification to make regulations for peace and good government, with force of law unless repugnant, may repeal/amend prior laws.

December 28, 1949: Government of Madhya Bharat issued notification under Rule 18 read with Rule 17 of Tax Rules amending them: (1) assessments by assessing officer instead of board; (2) first appeal to officer appointed by Minister in-charge of Finance instead of Member Commerce and Industry; (3) second appeals to High Court on point of law only instead of Government on facts and law.
January 26, 1950: Constitution of India came into force; Madhya Bharat became Part B State.

Finance Act No. 25 of 1950 effective April 1, 1950: repealed laws like Tax Rules after accounting year ending March 31, 1949 for levy/assessment/collection except for prior periods; assessments/references to be by corresponding authorities under Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.
Assessments for years 1940-1948 (before March 31, 1949) made by authorities under Tax Rules despite Finance Act provision for Income Tax Act authorities.

Madhya Bharat Taxes on Income Validation Act, No. 38 of 1954: Section 3 validates all proceedings/assessments done under relevant Madhya Bharat law for relevant period notwithstanding Finance Act proviso; Section 4 allows pending proceedings to continue under old law.
Appellant filed writ petition in Madhya Pradesh High Court (Indore Bench) in 1955 challenging assessments under Tax Rules.
Madhya Pradesh High Court dismissed writ petition by judgment dated January 2, 1959 in Civil Misc. Case No. 20 of 1955; granted certificate of fitness for appeal.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court: Civil Appeal No. 316 of 1962.

legal_issues.text: Validity of amendments to Indore Industrial Tax Rules, 1947 made on December 28, 1949 purporting under Rule 17.
Whether amendments could have retroactive effect taking away vested right of second appeal on facts.
Validity of assessments made by old authorities post-Finance Act 1950 and whether Validating Act 1954 validates them or is discriminatory under Article 14.

petitioner_arguments.text: Amendments of Tax Rules on December 28, 1949 invalid as could not be made under Rule 17 (power to frame rules does not include modifying parent law).
Even if amendments valid, could not have retroactive effect taking away vested right of appeal to Government on facts and law.
Assessments invalid as made by old Tax Rules authorities post-Finance Act instead of Income Tax Act authorities; Validating Act discriminatory (Art.14) and does not apply to these assessments.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Finance Act 1950 s.13 proviso; Article 14; Validating Act 1954

court_reasoning.text: Amendments valid under s.5(1) and (3) of Act 1 of 1948 (empowers Government to amend prior laws by notification); wrong reference to Rule 17 in notification does not vitiate as substance complied with publication requirement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Wrong recital of power does not invalidate if action justifiable under correct power.

court_reasoning.text: Amendments take away vested right of second appeal on facts by necessary intendment; new Rule 13 confines second appeal to questions of law only, required to align with new State structure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Vested right of appeal can be taken away by necessary implication.

court_reasoning.text: Validating Act not discriminatory (Art.14) as validates prior mistaken proceedings under old law which stand on different footing; specifically applies to 1940-48 assessments made by old authorities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Validating Act does exactly what needed for prior acts requiring validation.

holdings.text: Amendments to Tax Rules dated December 28, 1949 are valid under s.5 of Act 1 of 1948.
Amendments validly curtail second appeal to questions of law only by necessary intendment.
Assessments validated by Validating Act 1954, not hit by Art.14.

statutes_cited.relevance: Empowered amendments to Tax Rules as regulations

statutes_cited.name: Finance Act No. 25 of 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed Tax Rules post Mar 31,1949; required assessments by IT Act authorities

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Bharat Taxes on Income Validation Act, No. 38 of 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Validated prior assessments under old law

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income Tax Act, No. XI of 1922
Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Alleged discrimination by Validating Act rejected

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the Madhya Pradesh High Court's dismissal of the writ petition; all contentions regarding invalidity of 1949 amendments, vested appeal rights, and Validating Act rejected; assessments under Tax Rules for 1940-1948 validated.

key_quotes.text: It is well settled that merely a wrong reference to the power under which certain actions are taken by Government would not per se vitiate the actions done if they can be justified under some other power under which the Government could lawfully do these acts.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies amendments despite wrong recital of power

key_quotes.text: A Validating Act is passed only when certain things have been done which require validation. This is exactly what the present Validating Act has done and we fail to see on what grounds it can be said to be discriminatory.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects Art.14 challenge to Validating Act
